fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a category with pullbacks. The subobject classifier of \mathcal {C} is the terminal object (if it exists) of the category \mathcal {S}_{\mathcal {C}} defined by the following data:

html:tr.html:td: An object of \mathcal {S}_{\mathcal {C}} is a pair (A, m), where A is an object in \mathcal {C} and m\colon A' \rightarrowtail A is a subobject.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Identities and compositions of \mathcal {S}_{\mathcal {C}} are inherited from \mathcal {C}.

Let \mathcal {C} be a category with pullbacks. The subobject classifier of \mathcal {C} is the terminal object (if it exists) of the category \mathcal {S}_{\mathcal {C}} defined by the following data:

html:tr.html:td: An object of \mathcal {S}_{\mathcal {C}} is a pair (A, m), where A is an object in \mathcal {C} and m\colon A' \rightarrowtail A is a subobject.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Identities and compositions of \mathcal {S}_{\mathcal {C}} are inherited from \mathcal {C}.
An (elementary) topos is a finitely complete and cartesian closed category equipped with a subobject classifier.

fr:title.text: Categories with a subobject classifier are cartesian

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Categories with a subobject classifier are cartesian

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If \mathcal {C} is a category with pullbacks equipped with a subobject classifier then \mathcal {C} is cartesian.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By , \mathcal {C} has a terminal object. Thus, it follows that \mathcal {C} has all finite limits.

fr:title.text: Domain of the generic subobject is terminal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Domain of the generic subobject is terminal

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \top \colon \Omega '\to \Omega be the generic subobject of a category \mathcal {C} with pullbacks, then \Omega ' is terminal.

fr:title.text: Monomorphisms in a category equipped with a subobject classifier are regular

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monomorphisms in a category equipped with a subobject classifier are regular

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a cartesian category equipped with a subobject classifier. Every monomorphism in \mathcal {C} is regular.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
Note that the generic subobject \top \colon 1\rightarrowtail \Omega is a split monomorphism, so it is also a regular monomorphism. Explicitly, \top is the equalizer of \mathsf {id}_{\Omega } and \Omega \xrightarrow {\mathsf {!}_{\Omega }} 1 \xrightarrow {\top } \Omega .
Since every monomorphism in \mathcal {C} is a pullback against \top and regular monomorphisms are stable under pullback, it follows that every monomorphism in \mathcal {C} is regular.

fr:title.text: Explicit description of the subobject classifier

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Explicit description of the subobject classifier

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Explicitly, a subobject classifier is an object \Omega equipped with a generic subobject \top \colon \Omega ' \rightarrowtail \Omega such that for any subobject m\colon A' \rightarrowtail A, there is a unique classifying morphism \chi _{m}\colon A \to \Omega such that m is a pullback against \top along \chi _{m}.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = A', nw/style = pullback, ne = \Omega ', sw = A, se = \Omega , west = m, east = \top , west/style = {>->}, east/style = {>->}, south = \chi _{m}, south/style = {->,exists}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An (elementary) topos is a finitely complete and cartesian closed category equipped with a subobject classifier.

Let B be an object in a category \mathcal {C}. A subobject of B is a monomorphism m\colon A \rightarrowtail B. The category of subobjects of B, denoted as \mathsf {Sub}(B), is the full subcategory of {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}} spanned by monomorphisms.
